name: Describe changes and invariance following transformations

skills.name: Identify invariant points following a rotation
Identify invariant points following an enlargement
Identify that a translation cannot lead to any invariant points
Identify points of invariance that result from a combination of transformations

explanations.A: I think you have spotted that the shape looks the same following the reflection. Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place, has P stayed where it was?
explanations.B: Invariant points are points on a line or shape which do not move when a specific transformation is applied, in this case following the reflection Q and S have not moved.
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place, has P stayed where it was?
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place, check if this happens for any of the vertices here.

explanations.A: The only point of invariance is R, the centre of rotation (2,5), as all of the others will be twice as far from this point
explanations.B: Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place. Does Q remain at (4, 5) following the enlargement? Check all vertices.
explanations.C: Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place. Does Q remain at (4, 5) following the enlargement? Check all vertices.
explanations.D: Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place following the enlargement. Are there any vertices that don't move when the scale factor is applied?

explanations.A: Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place. Does A remain at (6, 6) following the enlargement? It is 3 right and 3 up from the centre, which would become 3 left and 3 down using the scale factor, moving it to (0, 0). Check all vertices.
explanations.B: Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place. Does B remain at (2, 4) following the enlargement? It is 1 left and 1 up from the centre, which would become 1 right and 1 down using the scale factor, moving it to (4, 2). Check all vertices.
explanations.C: Remember, invariant points must stay in exactly the same place. Does B remain at (2, 4) following the enlargement? It is 1 left and 1 up from the centre, which would become 1 right and 1 down using the scale factor, moving it to (4, 2). Check all vertices.
explanations.D: Invariant points must stay in exactly the same place following the enlargement. All of these labelled points will move, so there are no invariant points.

explanations.A: Not quite, an invariant point is one which has not moved, has R moved when it has been translated?
explanations.B: Not quite, an invariant point is one which has not moved, have Q, R or S moved when they have been translated?
explanations.C: Not quite, an invariant point is one which has not moved, have P, Q, R or S moved when they have been translated?
explanations.D: A translation cannot lead to any invariant points as all of the points have moved. In this case they ahve moved 2 right and 2 down.

explanations.A: Not quite, an invariant point is one which has not moved, have B and C moved when they have been translated?
explanations.B: Not quite, an invariant point is one which has not moved, have E and F moved when they have been translated?
explanations.C: Not quite, think about what happens to each point when it is translated, do they move or stay in the same place?
explanations.D: A translation cannot lead to any invariant points as all of the points have moved. In this case they have moved 2 left and 2 down.
